name: Baum–Connes conjecture
rephrased: The topological K-theory of a group's classifying space is isomorphic to the K-theory of its reduced C*-algebra via a specific map called the assembly map.
implication_form: Not applicable (the conjecture is an equality/isomorphism itself)
posed_by: H. Blumberg and G. Connes (or H. Baum and G. Connes)
explained: The Baum–Connes conjecture states that for any discrete group Γ, the assembly map \( \mu_Γ \colon \underset{\underline{E}Γ}{K}^*(BΓ) \to \mathrm{K}\text{\textunderscore{as}}^*(C^*_\mathrm{red}(Γ)) \) is an isomorphism of abelian groups. Here, \( \underset{\underline{E}Γ}{K}^*(BΓ) \) denotes the topological K-theory of the classifying space \( BΓ \) (the space representing the classifying bundle for principal Γ-bundles), \( C^*_\mathrm{red}(Γ) \) is the reduced group C*-algebra associated with Γ, and \( \mathrm{K}\text{\textunderscore{as}}^* \) is the analytic K-theory (the K-theory of the C*-algebra). The assembly map is a fundamental map that connects the topological and analytic aspects of the group.
